spanishExample: ¡Buenas noches! Nos estamos *preparing* para irnos.
englishTranslation: Good night! We are preparing ourselves in order to leave.
vocabIncluded: irse: any use of Ir with a reflexive pronoun, changing the meaning to "leave"
para: "in order", "in order to" before an infinitive

spanishExample: ¡Cuidado! No *I want* que hagas lo que yo hice.
englishTranslation: Carefull! I don’t want you to do what I did.
vocabIncluded: "lo que": "what" as a connector between phrases
"que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)

spanishExample: ¡Hágalo para ser su amiga!
englishTranslation: (formal, f) Do it in order to be her friend!
vocabIncluded: para: "in order", "in order to" before an infinitive

spanishExample: ¡Vamos! Tenemos que ir hasta *next week.*
englishTranslation: Let’s go! We have to go until next week.
vocabIncluded: using Tener with "que" to indicate obligation

spanishExample: ¿Cómo están en el trabajo?
englishTranslation: How are they at work?
vocabIncluded: cómo: adverb meaning "how?" in a question or implied question

spanishExample: ¿Cómo que yo no lo haría?
englishTranslation: What do you mean I wouldn’t do it?
vocabIncluded: haría: "would do/make", "I would do/make" (Hacer, conditional, 1st person)

spanishExample: ¿Cuál es su casa?
englishTranslation: Which is their house?

spanishExample: ¿Has ido a *the store?* ¡Tiene de todo!
englishTranslation: Have you gone to the store? It has everything!
vocabIncluded: has: "have", "you have" before a participle (Haber, present, 2nd person)
tiene de todo: "has some of everything" (idiom)

spanishExample: ¿No tienes nada para mí?
englishTranslation: You don’t have anything for me?

spanishExample: ¿Qué haría usted en mi lugar?
englishTranslation: What would you(formal) do in my place?
vocabIncluded: haría: "would do/make", "he/she/it would do/make" (Hacer, conditional, 3rd person)
usted: "you", formal subject pronoun, taking 3rd-person treatment

spanishExample: De nada, pero tengo que irme ahora.
englishTranslation: You’re welcome, but I have to leave now.
vocabIncluded: irse: any use of Ir with a reflexive pronoun, changing the meaning to "leave"
using Tener with "que" to indicate obligation

spanishExample: El chico hace su trabajo.
englishTranslation: The boy does his work.

spanishExample: Él *wants* que ella esté *where* tú habías estado.
englishTranslation: He wants her to be where you had been.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
habías: "had", "you had" before a participle (Haber, imperfect, 2nd person)

spanishExample: Ella hacía lo que yo hago ahora.
englishTranslation: She used to do what I do now.
vocabIncluded: "lo que": "what" as a connector between phrases
hacía: "was doing/making", "he/she/it was doing/making" (Hacer, imperfect, 3rd person)

spanishExample: Ella les *gave homework* en su *Spanish class.*
englishTranslation: She gave them homework in their Spanish class.
vocabIncluded: les: "them" as an indirect object ("to them", "for them")

spanishExample: Ella va y *she wants* que ellos vayan también.
englishTranslation: She is going and she wants them to go too.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)

spanishExample: Ellos han tenido la que ella hizo.
englishTranslation: They have had the one(f) that she made.
vocabIncluded: han: "have", "they have" before a participle (Haber, present, 3rd person plural)

spanishExample: En verdad está yendo ahora.
englishTranslation: Actually she is going(gerund) now.

spanishExample: Eran mis mejores amigos cuando estábamos en *school.*
englishTranslation: They were my best friends when we were in school.

spanishExample: Ese día tuve la mejor forma de hacerlo.
englishTranslation: That day I had the best way to do it.

spanishExample: Está *studying* para hacerse *lawyer.*
englishTranslation: She is studying in order to become a lawyer.
vocabIncluded: hacerse: any use of Hacer with a reflexive pronoun, changing the meaning to "become"
para: "in order", "in order to" before an infinitive

spanishExample: Esta vez tienes que irte.
englishTranslation: This time you have to leave.
vocabIncluded: irse: any use of Ir with a reflexive pronoun, changing the meaning to "leave"
using Tener with "que" to indicate obligation

spanishExample: Estaba ahí para tenerlo.
englishTranslation: She was there in order to have it(m).
vocabIncluded: ahí: adverb meaning "there", especially when close to the speaker or listener
para: "in order", "in order to" before an infinitive

spanishExample: Estamos de acuerdo, tiene que irse.
englishTranslation: We’re in agreement, she has to leave.
vocabIncluded: irse: any use of Ir with a reflexive pronoun, changing the meaning to "leave"
using Tener with "que" to indicate obligation

spanishExample: Estarías con nosotros.
englishTranslation: You would be with us.
vocabIncluded: estarías: "would be", "you would be" (Estar, conditional, 2nd person)

spanishExample: Fue la *winner* ese día con nosotros.
englishTranslation: She was the winner that day with us.

spanishExample: Fui y fui la que lo hizo con cuidado.
englishTranslation: I went and I was the one(f) that did it carefully.

spanishExample: Fuiste el problema ese día.
englishTranslation: You were the problem that day.

spanishExample: Habían hecho lo que hiciste.
englishTranslation: They had done what you did.
vocabIncluded: "lo que": "what" as a connector between phrases
habían: "had", "they had" before a participle (Haber, imperfect, 3rd person plural)

spanishExample: Habrá un problema con ellos.
englishTranslation: There will be a problem with them(m).
vocabIncluded: habrá: "there will be" indicating existence (Haber, future, impersonal)

spanishExample: Hacen tres pizzas.
englishTranslation: They are making three pizzas.

spanishExample: Haré esa.
englishTranslation: I will make that one(f).
vocabIncluded: haré: "will do/make", "I will do/make" (Hacer, future, 1st person)

spanishExample: Haremos más *food* porque no está de más.
englishTranslation: We’ll make more food because it couldn’t hurt.
vocabIncluded: haremos: "will do/make", "we will do/make" (Hacer, future, 1st person plural)
no está de más: "it couldn't hurt" (idiom)

spanishExample: Haz lo que te *I tell* y ten cuidado.
englishTranslation: Do what I tell you and be careful.
vocabIncluded: "lo que": "what" as a connector between phrases
te: "you" as an indirect object ("to you", "for you")
tener cuidado: "to be careful" (idiom, lit. "to have carefulness")

spanishExample: Hazlo si no *you want* que ella sea su amiga.
englishTranslation: Do it if you don’t want her to be his friend.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)

spanishExample: *I saw* a un amigo cuando estaba en Perú.
englishTranslation: I saw a friend when I was in Perú.
vocabIncluded: "the personal a": using an extra "a" before a direct object when it's a person

spanishExample: *I want* que lo haga a tiempo este año.
englishTranslation: I want him to do it on time this year.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)

spanishExample: La mujer no *wants* que vayas y no *wants* que lo hagan.
englishTranslation: The woman doesn’t want you to go and doesn’t want them to do it.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)

spanishExample: Le tengo que *tell* a mi amigo que tenemos un acuerdo.
englishTranslation: I have to tell my friend(m) that we have an agreement.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
a, used in a "redundant indirect object", e.g. le hice un favor a la chica
le: "her/him" as an indirect object ("to her/him", "for her/him")
using Tener with "que" to indicate obligation

spanishExample: Lo hará porque *she thinks* que hasta ellas estarían *happy.*
englishTranslation: She will do it, because she thinks even they(f) would be happy.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
estarían: "would be", "they would be" (Estar, conditional, 3rd person plural)
hará: "will do/make", "he/she/it will do/make" (Hacer, future, 3rd person)

spanishExample: Lo *important* es que ella *wants* que estén aquí.
englishTranslation: The important (thing) is that she wants them to be here.
vocabIncluded: "lo": "the" with no noun, as in "lo bueno"
"que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)

spanishExample: Lo tendría todo si hiciera lo que tú haces.
englishTranslation: I would have it all if I did what you do.
vocabIncluded: "lo que": "what" as a connector between phrases
tendría: "would have", "I would have" (Tener, conditional, 1st person)

spanishExample: Los tengo que tener sí o sí por esos días.
englishTranslation: I have to have them either way for those days.
vocabIncluded: using Tener with "que" to indicate obligation

spanishExample: Mi amiga iba a estar aquí.
englishTranslation: My friend(f) was going to be here.
vocabIncluded: iba: "was going", "he/she/it was going" (Ir, imperfect, 3rd person)
using Ir and "a" to put verbs in the future (e.g. "voy a ser")

spanishExample: Mi idea es más *smart* que la de todos.
englishTranslation: My idea is smarter than everyone’s.

spanishExample: No *they want* tenerte porque no fueron contigo.
englishTranslation: They don’t want to have you, because they didn’t go with you.

spanishExample: No, no fui.
englishTranslation: No, I didn’t go.

spanishExample: Nosotros también hemos hecho lo que hacías.
englishTranslation: We also have done what you used to do.
vocabIncluded: "lo que": "what" as a connector between phrases
hacías: "were doing/making", "you were doing/making" (Hacer, imperfect, 2nd person)
hemos: "have", "we have" before a participle (Haber, present, 1st person plural)

spanishExample: O está *cooking* o está *studying.*
englishTranslation: Either she is cooking or she is studying.

spanishExample: Por favor, no hacemos lo que yo hacía.
englishTranslation: Please, we aren’t doing what I used to do.
vocabIncluded: "lo que": "what" as a connector between phrases
hacía: "was doing/making", "I was doing/making" (Hacer, imperfect, 1st person)

spanishExample: Se la *she gave* a ustedes y es buena.
englishTranslation: She gave it(f) to all of you and it’s good.
vocabIncluded: "se" to mean "le" or "les", as in "se lo" or "se la"
a, used in a "redundant indirect object", e.g. le hice un favor a la chica
ustedes: plural "you" after a preposition (prep. pronoun)

spanishExample: *She wants* que yo haga su trabajo.
englishTranslation: She wants me to do her work.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)

spanishExample: Si él fuera a *the party,* yo sería *a happy person.*
englishTranslation: If he went to the party, I would be a happy person.
vocabIncluded: sería: "would be", "I would be" (Ser, conditional, 1st person)

spanishExample: Si ella estuviera por ahí, tendríamos un problema.
englishTranslation: If she were around, we would have a problem.
vocabIncluded: tendríamos: "would have", "we would have" (Tener, conditional, 1st person plural)

spanishExample: Si tuviera el trabajo, lo haría.
englishTranslation: If I had the job, I would do it.
vocabIncluded: haría: "would do/make", "I would do/make" (Hacer, conditional, 1st person)

spanishExample: Si yo fuera *where* ellos estaban, tendría una razón.
englishTranslation: If I went to where they were, I would have a reason.
vocabIncluded: tendría: "would have", "I would have" (Tener, conditional, 1st person)

spanishExample: Sí, estábamos ahí.
englishTranslation: Yes, we were there.
vocabIncluded: ahí: adverb meaning "there", especially when close to the speaker or listener

spanishExample: Sí, por si algo *happens.*
englishTranslation: Yes, in case something happens.

spanishExample: Ten esta *pie* que hicimos.
englishTranslation: Have this pie(f) that we made.

spanishExample: Tendrás un problema con ella.
englishTranslation: You will have a problem with her.
vocabIncluded: tendrás: "will have", "you will have" (Tener, future, 2nd person)

spanishExample: Tenemos que *arrive* a las 2 en vez de a las 3.
englishTranslation: We have to arrive at 2 instead of at 3.
vocabIncluded: using Tener with "que" to indicate obligation

spanishExample: Tenías que ir con tu amiga ese día, pero no fuiste.
englishTranslation: You had to go with your friend(f) that day, but you didn’t go.
vocabIncluded: using Tener with "que" to indicate obligation

spanishExample: *They want* que seamos mejores que ellos.
englishTranslation: They want us to be better than them(m).
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)

spanishExample: Tienen el que *you want.*
englishTranslation: They have the one(m) that you want.

spanishExample: Tienes que estar en la casa de Ana a la una.
englishTranslation: You have to be at Ana’s house at 1.
vocabIncluded: using Tener with "que" to indicate obligation

spanishExample: Tienes que *study* para hacerte *doctor.*
englishTranslation: You have to study in order to become a doctor.
vocabIncluded: para: "in order", "in order to" before an infinitive
using Tener with "que" to indicate obligation

spanishExample: Tienes razón; tengo que hacerlo.
englishTranslation: You’re right; I have to do it.
vocabIncluded: tener razón: "to be right" (idiom, lit. "to have reason")
using Tener with "que" to indicate obligation

spanishExample: Tú harás mejor tu *homework* con nosotras.
englishTranslation: You will do your homework better with us(f).
vocabIncluded: harás: "will do/make", "you will do/make" (Hacer, future, 2nd person)

spanishExample: Uno tiene que hacerle un favor esta tarde.
englishTranslation: One has to do him a favor this afternoon.
vocabIncluded: using Tener with "que" to indicate obligation
